entry.title: [Iter-X] 36/100days
entry.content:
Day3Ô∏è‚É£6Ô∏è‚É£

App TestFlight

Today I organized the client app‚Äôs icons, name, and such, and also sent it out on TestFlight. Over the next couple of days, I‚Äôll focus on infrastructure, and then we can start pushing the pages.

I feel that the loose collaboration style is not ideal. It‚Äôs already difficult to find people who can stick with it, and with part-time work, everyone‚Äôs time and energy are unpredictable. On top of that, continuous input is needed, which really filters out most people. But I think this is an interesting phenomenon. This is my first time trying to attract others through social media. Watching everyone‚Äôs evolution from initial idea exchanges to different behaviors as time goes on has been a fascinating process. I think this kind of collaboration, combining open-source principles with social platforms, is very dynamic and helps with learning. It further validates my idea that entrepreneurship can‚Äôt just rely on close relationships; you can‚Äôt naively assume that your good friends are the best people to work with. Instead, you should look for that ‚Äúone in a million‚Äù person. Perhaps this also indirectly explains why there are more solo entrepreneurs ‚Äî finding the right partners is not easy. Is this a bit pessimistic? I‚Äôm still optimistic. I have a strong ability to balance my own emotions and pressures. When you want to attract and lead others toward a distant future, you need to be strong enough to handle most situations. When everyone else falls, you still have to stand. If you don‚Äôt have this mindset, then just close your laptop and enjoy a 9-to-5 job, balancing life and work. No need to burn your life doing something you don‚Äôt enjoy.

Recently, I‚Äôve been thinking about exploring further how AI can help improve my efficiency and productivity. A lot of what‚Äôs online is just demo-style sharing, but I‚Äôm looking for something practical that can actually assist. If you know about this and are willing to share, feel free to DM me üöÄ

Summary of current progress:

  1. Prototype design & UI/UX design: 30%
  2. Backend (Go) development: 30%
  3. Client app (Flutter) progress: 12%
  4. Data: 8%

If you think you meet the following criteria, feel free to reach out (we‚Äôre looking for a UI design partner üëæ):

  1. Able to stick with it
  2. Dream-driven
  3. Interested

entry.title: [Iter-X] 34/100days
entry.content:
Day3Ô∏è‚É£4Ô∏è‚É£

AI for Trip Planing

A friend sent me a smart planning feature from Gaode. You input ‚Äú3-day trip to Hangzhou,‚Äù and it starts planning. It even outputs the reasoning process of the model. I suddenly felt a bit absurd ‚Äì the user just entered these five words, and AI is already thinking? It feels almost magical. It doesn‚Äôt even ask for user preferences. Is this kind of forced reasoning really thinking? I feel like many product teams today are missing the point. It‚Äôs like the famous story of Steve Jobs talking to his engineers. Today, many teams make the same mistake: they prioritize technology over product. Essentially, it‚Äôs ‚ÄúAI first.‚Äù In reality, we should start from the user. Only then should we think about whether this technology is needed, where it‚Äôs needed, to what extent, and what it can achieve. This is the logical direction to consider. Of course, I understand that FOMO, KPIs, and other pressures can lead to this approach, but just because it‚Äôs ‚Äúnecessary‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs the right approach.

I even think we should let AI have a certain attitude. For instance, if you provide too little information, we shouldn‚Äôt recommend anything. Because it‚Äôs easy to recommend incorrectly, and the outcome could be: 1) The user feels like it doesn‚Äôt work and quits. 2) The user manually deletes the recommendation. 3) Or the user keeps asking AI to optimize it. Essentially, we‚Äôre wasting computational power, which equals burning money to satisfy unclear needs, guessing user preferences in a labor-intensive way, which is not productive.

If we must force AI to recommend based on such limited information, that‚Äôs fine. We can go with a safer, more generic approach. This can meet the needs of the majority of users, especially those visiting a place for the first time. The chances are they will want to see the more famous attractions.

Another point is that recommendations need to be justified. The reason for recommending a specific POI should be clear to the user because users have the final decision. For example, when browsing travel spots on platforms like Xiaohongshu or social media, you don‚Äôt visit all the top 10 places. You will only go to those that interest you. The key is understanding why something interests you.

I still think we need to return to the original goal: start with a useful itinerary planner, then make it smarter. Many products today only focus on a direction or a few points, but what users expect is a complete product. We want to deliver this complete product. Now, I actually feel happier and lighter because the real concern for me was the financial pressure AI would bring. If we can get our approach right, maybe we don‚Äôt need such high upfront costs to validate whether the market believes in our vision.

Current status summary:

  1. Prototype & UI/UX design: 29%
  2. Backend (Go) development: 30%
  3. Frontend (Flutter) progress: 8%
  4. Data: 8%

entry.title: [Iter-X] 32/100days
entry.content:
Day3Ô∏è‚É£2Ô∏è‚É£

AI for Trip Planing

The AI architecture and overall framework are complete, and an intelligent itinerary creation process is now running successfully. However, there are still some tasks to tackle:

  1. Consider integrating MCP for further standardization.
  2. Enhance observability‚ÄîLLM calls need monitoring, including cost tracking, input-output sampling, etc., to support future Agent version iterations with data.
  3. Strengthen boundary handling to ensure fallback mechanisms in certain scenarios.
  4. Standardize prompt version management.
  5. Optimize full-text search‚Äîconsider replacing Elasticsearch with Postgres, which should be sufficient for a long time.
  6. Improve Agents and Tools.

These tasks can be addressed progressively. Now that the framework is in place, AI engineers can focus on optimization, backend developers can implement logic, and data engineers can integrate data.

Current Progress:

  • Prototype Design & UI/UX: 28%
  • Backend (Go) Development: 30%
  • Client (Flutter) Progress: 8%
  • Data: 8%

  2. Ambitious
  3. Passionate

Let‚Äôs build something amazing together! üëæ

entry.title: [Iter-X] 31/100days
entry.content:
Day3Ô∏è‚É£1Ô∏è‚É£

Map

Today, I imported some POI data and conducted a full-text search. Tomorrow, I‚Äôll continue working on the AI workflow. I also had a chat with two product teammates, and along with my recent thoughts, I took some time to brainstorm ideas.

Lately, I came across another person doing a ‚ÄúBuild in Public 100 Days‚Äù challenge, also working on a travel app. Several friends mentioned it to me today and even asked if we were on the same team‚Äîhaha. This also led me to write an article yesterday reflecting on our product, going back to the core idea, and defining why our product can survive in the market, what makes it different, and what value it brings to users. This actually helped me further clarify my thoughts. I believe delivering a good product to the market isn‚Äôt the hard part‚Äîsurvival is. Entering the travel planning app space sometimes feels like ‚Äúseeking my own demise.‚Äù After all, the dominant players in this industry are OTAs (Online Travel Agencies), which hold the key B2B resources and have massive user bases‚Äîan enormous moat. On the other hand, many products that started as tools have struggled to monetize, leading to shutdowns. Another challenge is the low barrier to entry‚Äîmany people can build similar products, and independent creators often go for small, niche, and paid products.

So, why start despite all this? Anyone with some business knowledge can analyze these challenges, but I believe the world still needs a bit of irrationality and courage. Andrea used a word today that I found fitting‚ÄîUtopia. Deep down, my rational self still holds a touch of impulsive passion, perhaps influenced by my wild, self-taught experience in the arts. I enjoy painting bold strokes of creativity against a logical backdrop.

Right now, no single app allows me to fully manage my travel experience from start to finish. Travelers today are ‚ÄúFrankenstein users,‚Äù constantly piecing together information from different sources, recording bits here and there. Travel can be a one-time, fleeting joy or a lifelong collection of experiences‚Äîit all depends on how you define it. I want to create an app that I can use for a lifetime.

Current Progress:

  • Prototype & UI/UX Design: 28%
  • Backend (Go) Development: 27%
  • Client (Flutter) Development: 8%
  • Data: 8%

entry.title: [Iter-X] 30/100days
entry.content:
Day3Ô∏è‚É£0Ô∏è‚É£

Wiki

Time flies so quickly‚Äîit‚Äôs already been 30 days, and we‚Äôve completed 1/3 of the journey. Without realizing it, our small team has grown to 13 people. Today, some team members shared a few competitions, both AI-focused and startup-related. We plan to participate in a few and see how we can contribute. This also pushes us to quickly deliver some demos and prepare investment pitch materials. We expect to have a working demo this week; both the client and AI components are still being worked on. The team is deeply focused on the overall AI framework and ensuring everything flows smoothly. We aim to have everything up and running by tomorrow or the day after at the latest.

We should be launching an official account soon to post content, though we haven‚Äôt fully decided on the content production strategy yet. That‚Äôs it for now‚Äîback to work.

entry.title: [Iter-X] 29/100days
entry.content:
Day2Ô∏è‚É£9Ô∏è‚É£

Daily Itinerary

Two new teammates have joined the team, filling the gap in product operations. We also have a C-end product role now‚Äîlooking forward to future outputs!

Today, I focused on handling the AI architecture. It‚Äôs mostly sorted out, and tomorrow, I‚Äôll integrate an instance to connect the entire process. On the backend side, we plan to integrate MCP and align with some open-source protocols. MCP itself is an initiative aimed at resolving the chaotic Function Call implementations across different vendors. This should have been something OpenAI led, but since it‚Äôs focused on for-profit commercialization, Claude has taken up the mantle. MCP was released last year but has only recently gained traction among developers. Now, various services are starting to build MCP Servers for their platforms. Currently, the only usable client-side applications seem to be Cursor and the Claude app, and an MCP application marketplace is expected to emerge rapidly.

If you‚Äôre a UI designer, feel free to reach out! Right now, I‚Äôm also handling UI design. While I can translate my ideas into designs effectively, we still need a designer with a unique style and vision to elevate the overall design.

Current Progress Summary:

  1. Prototype Design & UI/UX: 27%
  2. Backend (Go) Development: 25%
  3. Client (Flutter) Progress: 7%
  4. Data: 6%

entry.title: [Iter-X] 28/100days
entry.content:
Day2Ô∏è‚É£8Ô∏è‚É£

Trip Page

This weekend, I‚Äôve mainly been working on the design of the AI architecture. The PR is still in DRAFT status and isn‚Äôt fully completed yet; it‚Äôs expected to take another two days to finish. In the evenings, I managed to spare some time to refactor and optimize the main itinerary page. It‚Äôs still a half-finished project, but over the past month of practice, my understanding of prototype + UI design has improved. However, there‚Äôs still a long way to go in terms of aesthetics. I plan to take some time to further develop my taste and artistic sense. I actually get quite anxious when I see others‚Äô designs not aligning with my vision. I think many people feel the same way‚Äîmost will just say they don‚Äôt like something or that it‚Äôs not good enough, but they might struggle to pinpoint exactly what‚Äôs wrong. I‚Äôm really fond of the concept of being a polymath or a learned person, someone who has deep knowledge in a few areas. For an independent creator, it feels like knowing just one thing isn‚Äôt enough. You need to have unique insights in several areas to see clearly on the big picture and understand the details as well.

Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Code, MCP‚Äîif you haven‚Äôt been paying attention to these keywords lately, you might want to take note. These are currently trending in the frontier fields, and I‚Äôve been experimenting with applying them in real projects and engineering. There are a lot of thoughts and feelings around this. AI replacing most jobs is definitely not just hype. If you try it seriously, you‚Äôll be disheartened to realize how fragile many professions are under the relentless forward momentum of AI. Based on this, you have to stay on track and not get left behind. Don‚Äôt be fooled by the overwhelming Demo-style marketing online. Many exaggerated self-media channels can gradually lull you into complacency. The consequence is that you‚Äôll miss out on new trends simply because you weren‚Äôt aware. If you want to exchange ideas or learn about the latest trends in AI, feel free to reach out to me. It‚Äôs completely free. I hope to create a small group where we can exchange cutting-edge information, follow relevant papers, news, and startup updates. If you‚Äôre interested, feel free to follow me and DM me.

entry.title: [Iter-X] 27/100days
entry.content:
Day2Ô∏è‚É£7Ô∏è‚É£

Today I‚Äôve been focusing on the overall architecture and framework of the AI. The plan is to first implement the PlanAgent and streamline the process, so that the entire framework is thought through and other people can contribute based on this direction. I‚Äôm planning to stick to the previous design where we register multiple agents, and each agent can register a series of toolsets. This way, each agent can share tools when handling specific tasks. Currently, agents don‚Äôt communicate with each other, because the main goal right now is to integrate AI into the business layer‚Äôs various modules. Later, when we have a fully controlled AI, we will extract a main scheduling role in the business layer, where we can consider implementing multi-agent coordination to complete a task. This will also integrate routing gating. Overall, we‚Äôll still follow a multi-layered architecture where the upper layers can repeatedly reuse lower-layer instances, and lower layers are treated as ‚Äúatomic capabilities‚Äù by the upper layers.

Summary of the current situation:

  1. Prototype & UI/UX Design: 25%
  2. Backend (Go) Development: 23%
  3. Client (Flutter) Progress: 6%
  4. Data: 6%

  1. Persistent
  2. Have dreams
  3. Interested
